message_1: A company produces car tires and wants to estimate the mean lifespan of a particular brand of tire. A random sample of 50 tires was taken and the mean lifespan was found to be 42,000 miles with a standard deviation of 2,500 miles. Calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true mean lifespan of the tires.
message_2:
To calculate a 95% confidence interval for the true mean lifespan of the tires, we will use the formula:

Confidence interval = x̄ ± (z * (s / √n))

where:
x̄ = sample mean = 42,000 miles
z = z-score for a 95% confidence interval = 1.96 (from a standard normal distribution table)
s = sample standard deviation = 2,500 miles
n = sample size = 50 tires

First, we will calculate the standard error (SE):

SE = s / √n = 2,500 / √50 ≈ 353.55

Now, we will calculate the margin of error (ME):

ME = z * SE = 1.96 * 353.55 ≈ 692.96

Finally, we will calculate the confidence interval:

Lower limit = x̄ - ME = 42,000 - 692.96 ≈ 41,307.04 miles
Upper limit = x̄ + ME = 42,000 + 692.96 ≈ 42,692.96 miles

So, the 95% confidence interval for the true mean lifespan of the tires is approximately (41,307.04 miles, 42,692.96 miles).
